of property which causes any noxious or unwholesome liquid or substance to flow into or upon any street gutter alley sidewalk or public place within the city i air pollution the escape of smoke soot cinders noxious acids fumes gases fly ash industrial dust or other atmospheric pollutants within the city or within one mile therefrom in such quantities as to endanger the health of persons of ordinary sensibilities or threaten or cause substantial damage to property in the city 0315 710   public nuisances offending morals and decency the following acts omissions places conditions and things are specifically declared to be public nuisances offending public morals and decency but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances offending public morals and decency coming within the definition of a disorderly houses all disorderly houses bawdy houses houses of illfame gambling houses and buildings or structures kept or resorted to for the purpose of prostitution promiscuous sexual intercourse or gambling b gambling devices all gambling devices and slot machines c unlicensed sale of liquor and beer all places where alcohol beverages are sold possessed stored brewed bottled manufactured or rectified without a permit or license as provided for by the ordinances of the city d continuous violation of city ordinances any place or premises within the city where city ordinances or state laws relating to public health safety peace morals or welfare are openly continuously repeatedly and intentionally violated e illegal drinking any place or premises resorted to for the purpose of drinking intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverages in violation of state laws f public urinationdefecationvomiting prohibited no person shall defecate vomit or urinate in any public place on any public property or on any private property not designed intended and approved for such use example a public restroom or portable satellite facility violations of this section shall be subject to the forfeiture established by the city and the court may require upon conviction that the offender pay as restitution the actual costs of cleaning up a public or private place as a result of a prohibited act   prior code  1004   51314    public nuisances affecting peace and safety the following acts omissions places conditions and things are declared to be public nuisances affecting peace and safety  but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances affecting public peace or safety coming within the definition of a dangerous signs and billboards all signs billboards awnings and other similar structures over or near streets sidewalks public grounds or places frequented by the public so situated or constructed as to endanger the public safety b illegal buildings all buildings erected repaired or altered in violation of city ordinances relating to materials and manner of construction of buildings and structures within the city c unauthorized traffic signs all unauthorized signs signals markings or devices placed or maintained upon or in view of any public highway or railway crossing which purport to be or may be mistaken as official traffic control devices or railroad signs or signals or which because of their color location brilliance or manner of operation interfere with the effectiveness of any such device sign or signal d obstruction of intersections all trees hedges billboards or other obstructions which prevent persons driving vehicles on public streets alleys or highways from obtaining a clear view of traffic when approaching an intersection or pedestrian crosswalk e lowhanging tree limbs all limbs of trees which project over and less than ten 10 feet above any public sidewalk street or other public place f dangerous trees all trees which are a menace to public safety or are the cause of substantial annoyance to the general public g fireworks all use or display of fireworks except as provided by state laws and city ordinances h dilapidated buildings all buildings or structures so old dilapidated or out of repair as to be dangerous unsafe unsanitary or otherwise unfit for human use i lowhanging wires and cables all wires and cables over streets alleys or public grounds which are strung less than fifteen 15 feet above the surface thereof j noisy animals or fowl the keeping or harboring of any animal or fowl which by frequent or habitual howling yelping barking crowing or making of other noises greatly annoys or disturbs a neighborhood or any considerable number of persons within the city k obstructions of streetsexcavations all obstructions of streets alleys sidewalks or crosswalks and all excavations in or under the same except as permitted by the ordinances of the city but including those which although made in accordance with such ordinances are kept or maintained for an unreasonable or illegal length of time after the purpose thereof has been accomplished or which do not conform to the permit l unlawful assemblies any unauthorized or unlawful use of property abutting on a public street alley or sidewalk or of a public street alley or sidewalk which causes large crowds of people to gather obstructing traffic and free use of the streets or sidewalks 05   abatement of public nuisances a enforcement the city officials shall enforce those provisions of this chapter that come within the jurisdiction of their offices  and they shall make periodic inspections and inspections upon complaint to insure that such provisions are not violated no action shall be taken under this section to abate a public nuisance unless the officer has inspected or caused to be inspected the premises where the nuisance is alleged to exist and has satisfied himself that a nuisance does in fact exist b summary abatement if the inspecting officer determines that a public nuisance exists within the city and that there is great and immediate danger to the public health safety peace morals or decency the mayor may direct the proper officer to cause the same to be abated and charge the cost thereof to the owner occupant or person causing permitting or maintaining the nuisance as the case may be c abatement after notice if the inspecting officer determines that a public nuisance exists on private premises but that such nuisance does not threaten great and immediate danger to the public health safety peace morals or decency he or she shall serve notice on the person causing or maintaining the nuisance to remove the same within ten 10 days if such nuisance is not removed within ten 10 days the proper officer shall cause the nuisance to be removed as provided in subsection b of this section d other methods not excluded nothing in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting the abatement of public nuisances by the city or its officials in accordance with the laws of the state e court order except when necessary under subsection b of this section an officer hereunder shall not use force to obtain access to private property to abate a public nuisance but shall request permission to enter upon private property if such premises are occupied and if such permission is denied shall apply to any court having jurisdiction for an order assisting the abatement of the public nuisance 10   cost of abatement in addition to any other penalty imposed by this chapter for the erection contrivance creation continuance or maintenance of a public nuisance the cost of abating a public nuisance by the city shall be collected as a debt from the owner occupant person causing permitting or maintaining the nuisance  and if notice to abate the nuisance has been given to the owner such cost shall be assessed against the real estate as a special charge 11 solid waste collection and disposal footnotes  1  editors note  adopted  repealed the former  and  2 of enacted a new as set out herein the former pertained to similar subject matter and derived from prior code  11051110514 1110      adopted    regulated no person shall dispose of solid waste in the city except as provided in this section  2222011   definitions for the purpose of this section the following terms shall have the meaning stated alleyside means at the edge of the abutting alley of the rear yard of the residence appliances or white goods includes refrigerators freezers dryers washers stoves large furniture other appliances box springs mattresses and uncut carpeting certified landfill means any landfill that is properly licensed and approved by the city for use certified recycling facility means any recycling facility approved by the city for use compact fluorescent bulbs or cfls means a type of fluorescent lamp that is designed to replace an incandescent lamp and can fit into most existing light fixtures formerly used for incandescent cfls are more energy efficient than incandescent bulbs curbside means at the curb of the abutting front yard street of the residence demolition debris means waste resulting from the demolition of buildings and other manmade structures which may include untreated wood masonry glass and plastic building parts demolition debris does not include asbestos waste clean fill nor treated wood products duplex see unit fluorescent light bulbs means a glass tube coated inside with fluorescent substance giving off light when mercury vapor in the tube is acted upon by electrons from the cathode multiplefamily dwelling means a property containing four or more residential units nonresidential facilities and properties means commercial retail industrial institutional and government facilities and properties this term does not include multiplefamily dwellings plastic containers means an individual separate rigid plastic bottle can jar or carton except for a blister pack that is originally used to contain a product that is the subject of retail sale postconsumer waste means solid waste other than 1 solid waste generated in the production of goods  2 hazardous waste as defined in wis stats  3 waste from construction and demolition of structures scrap automobiles  or 4 highvolume industrial waste as defined in wis stats refuse tag means a tag purchased and attached to a bag of refuse to compensate the refuse hauler for disposal said tags are utilized when the standard refuse container is full residences means private dwellings apartments three dwelling units or less and rooming houses recyclables means products that can be collected and remanufactured into new products after theyve been used rooming house means a building arranged or used for lodging for compensation without meals and not occupied as a singlefamily unit solid waste has meaning given in wis stats triplex see unit unit means a singlefamily residential home a duplex shall be treated as two units a triplex as three units and a rooming house with five rooms or less as one unit each five rooms of the rooming house or increment thereof shall be treated as one unit example six rooms   two units  eleven 11 rooms   three units white goods see appliances yard waste has meaning given in wis stats  2222011   purpose the purpose of this section is to maintain and protect the public health and sanitation by the removal of solid waste from residences in the city and to prevent any unregulated and unrestricted hauling of solid waste by means other than solid waste collection system established by this section so as to eliminate the disposal of solid waste along the streets roads and other properties in and near the city  2222011   collection by the city a residential collection all solid waste accumulated in residential units in the city together with such other solid waste which is the responsibility of the city or which is accumulated by the city or for the city shall be collected conveyed and disposed of by the city or its authorized contractor no person shall collect or dispose of any solid waste accumulated on residential unit premises of the city except the city or its designated contractor for duplexes and triplexes the default action by the city will be to include them in the city contract for solid waste and recycling services however these facilities may opt out of service as explained below in addition a duplex may have one set of containers to service both units for condominium units the default action by the city will be to include them in the city contract for solid waste and recycling services however the city may allow a condominium unit to opt out in cases where the property is not suitable to individual service such as cases where the units are stacked and no individual outside entrances for the units exist for a multiplefamily dwelling four units or more the default action by the city will be to assume they will provide their own solid waste and recycling services however if a multifamily dwelling desires to be a part of the city contract this may be allowed at the citys discretion notwithstanding the above owners of residences that are part of or contiguous to a commercial property under the same ownership and owners of duplexes triplexes or rooming houses or other multiplefamily dwellings may make private arrangements with any licensed hauler the owner may choose for the removal of the solid waste accumulated for those units an owner choosing this option shall file a written notice with the city clerk stating the property address the number of units and the licensed hauler that has been contracted with the citys contractor shall not pick up solid waste at the exempt address nor shall the citys contractor charge the city or resident for any pickup at that residence if this private option is chosen solid waste shall be picked up at the exempt residence on at least a weekly basis and recycling shall be picked up on at least a biweekly basis if solid waste is not being picked up at an exempt residence for any reason at least one each week the city in its sole discretion can terminate the exemption by written notification to the owner at which time the residence goes back on city solid waste collection b accumulation by nonresidential facilities solid waste and recyclables accumulated by nonresidential facilities shall be properly disposed of by the owner renter or other occupant of the premises appliances or white goods as defined above shall not be considered solid waste and the owner of each property wishing to dispose of such goods must make independent arrangements with any hauler for the pickup of these items and pay the hauler directly for their disposal c separation and processing of recyclables 1 recyclables occupants of singlefamily duplexes triplexes rooming houses multiplefamily dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties in the city shall separate materials from their postconsumer waste as outlined in wis stats in addition to state requirements fluorescent light bulbs and compact florescent bulbs shall also be diverted from the postconsumer waste 2 care of separated materials to the greatest extent practicable the recyclable materials separated in accordance with subsection c1 of this section shall be clean and kept free of contaminates such as food or product residue oil and grease or other nonrecyclable materials including but not limited to household hazardous waste medical waste and agriculture chemical containers recyclable materials shall be stored in a manner which protects them from wind rain and other inclement weather conditions 3 management of lead acid batteries white goods waste oil and yard waste occupants of singlefamily duplexes triplexes and rooming houses multiplefamily dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties shall manage fluorescent light bulbs lead acid batteries white goods waste oil and yard waste as follows a fluorescent light bulbs shall be taken to the pierce county recycling center or residents can contact a licensed vendor to properly dispose of fluorescent bulbs  b compact fluorescent bulbs cfls shall be recycled at river falls municipal utility or at a recycling facility  c lead acid batteries shall be taken to an area retail business that sells vehicle batteries  d white goods shall be collected and recycled by the citys hauler for a fee taken to the pierce county recycling center or other certified recycling facility  e waste oil shall be brought to a designated waste oil collection site contact the city for a list of designated sites  f yard waste shall be managed onsite or brought to a municipal compost facility yard waste shall not be placed in a landfill or incinerator 4 preparation and collection of recyclable materials except as otherwise directed by the city of river falls occupants of singlefamily duplex triplex and rooming house residences shall do the following for the preparation and collection of the separated materials specified in subsection c1 of this section a if applicable items shall be rinsed clean  b remove any covers and pumps  c items shall be placed in the approved recycling cart and placed curbside or alleyside on the day designated for collection or they shall be placed in the designated receptacle of an established dropoff site during the days and hours of operation  d waste tires shall be collected by the citys hauler for a fee brought to a licensed tire collection facility or brought to the pierce county recycling center 5 multiplefamily dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties owners or designated agents of these properties in the city that are not participating in city contracted collection shall do all the following unless postconsumer waste generated in those properties is treated at a processing facility that recovers for recycling the material specified in 3 wis stats from that solid waste in as pure a form as is technically feasible a provide adequate containers for the recycling program established in compliance with this section  b notify all users tenants and occupants in writing at the time of renting or leasing and at least semiannually thereafter about the programs in this section  c provide for the collection of recyclables materials separated from the solid waste by the tenants and the delivery of the receptacle materials to a recycling facility  d notify tenants of reasons to reduce and recycle solid waste which materials are collected how to prepare recyclable materials in order to meet the processing requirement collection methods or sites locations and hours of operation and a contact person or company including a name address and phone number 6 procedures and penalties procedures for prosecuting and penalties for violating this section will be the responsible party designated  2222011   residential solid waste and recycling containers a solid waste containers the owner or resident of each residence on city garbage service shall be provided a container for refuse by the city or its contracted hauler each residential unit shall be allowed one container per week for the base charge of solid waste a residential unit may if desired place additional containers for pickup if the containers have the required refuse tag attached additional containers will not be collected if tags are not attached and residential occupants will be so notified by the citys hauler by virtue of placing a noncollection notice on the additional containers b recycling container the owner or residence on city garbage service shall be provided a container for recyclables from the city or its contracted hauler c residential solid waste and recycling containers shall be stored out of view as much as possible but shall be readily accessible on the curbside or alleyside on the day of collection d nonresidential facilities and properties refuse and recycling shall be stored in containers with covers when located outside a building  2222011   collection practices a solid waste shall be collected at least once each week according to a schedule to be determined and notice given by the collector at least two weeks in advance b collection locations shall not be changed by the hauler without consent from the city c no person shall place any solid waste or recyclables at the collection point more than eighteen 18 hours prior to the regular scheduled pickup  2222011   reserved   burning solid waste no person shall burn any solid waste within the city except as provided by city ordinances  2222011   marking of vehicles the holder of a license or contract for solid waste and recycling shall have the vehicles used for that purpose conspicuously marked with the haulers name and refuse collection permit number on the cab doors such vehicles shall comply with all state regulations and shall be subject to inspection by the city  2222011   spillage or leakage of solid waste all solid waste recycling and yard waste hauled on public streets in the city shall be securely tied and covered so as to prevent leakage spilling or blowing no person shall allow any solid waste recycling or yard waste to leak spill blow or drop from any vehicle on any public street within the city  2222011   fees a the fee schedule for residential collection shall be approved by the common council and shall be on file with the city clerk b fees shall be collected by the city or its contracted hauler as established in the city contract for solid waste and recycling services c for billing purposes a duplex shall typically be considered as two billing units a triplex as three billing units and rooming houses shall be charged at the established per unit rate however if the property opts for less containers than units as allowed in a they shall be billed appropriately for the number of containers serviced at the property d collection of delinquent accounts for solid waste and recycling services shall be in accordance with this code  2222011   1 1262016   financing the cost of operation of the residential solid waste and waste collection system shall be paid from fees established in this section  2222011   unlawful disposal no person shall dispose of solid waste other than as stated above no person or business shall place their solid waste on another persons property or in a private or public dumpster unless written permission has been obtained from the owner no person shall place any solid waste or yard waste in any street alley or other public place or upon any private property whether owned by such person or not within the city limits unless it is in proper containers for collection nor shall any person throw and deposit any solid waste or yard waste in any stream or other body of water any unauthorized accumulation of solid waste is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited no person shall cast place or deposit anywhere within the city any solid waste in such manner that it might be carried or deposited by the elements upon any street sidewalk sewer parkway or other public place or into any occupied premises within the city nothing contained herein shall prohibit individual properly maintained compost piles  2222011   notice adequate notice of the revisions and additions to this section shall be transmitted to the citizens via written or electronic communications or notices with utility billings or notices in the city newsletter  2222011   1 1262016   penalty except as otherwise provided any person who violates any provision of this chapter or any regulation rule or order made hereunder shall be subject to a penalty as provided in of this code  2222011 weeds and noxious growth footnotes     036   purpose a property in the city shall be maintained in a manner which does not present a health or safety hazard to owners of adjacent parcels of real estate and in a manner which does not detract from the appearance of the neighborhood and the value of real estate in the vicinity b all areas on a lot not used for buildings driveways walkways parking areas or other permitted improvements shall be established with suitable vegetation to prevent erosion due to wind and water part   definitions destroy means the complete killing of weeds or the killing of weed plants above the surface of the ground by the use of chemicals cutting tillage cropping system pasturing live stock or any or all of these in effective combination at such time and in such manner as will effectually prevent such plants from maturing to the bloom or flower stage garden means cultivated and defined areas containing perennials annuals trees shrubs flowers ornamental grasses agricultural crops vegetables or native plantings used for aesthetic andor wildlife promotion land management plan means a written plan related to management of the lawn which contains a legal description of the lawn upon which the grass or other plantings will exceed six inches in length a statement of intent and purpose for the lawn a general description of the vegetation types plants and plant succession involved and the specified management and maintenance techniques to be employed the management plan must include provisions for cutting at a length not greater that six inches in the boulevard area that portion between the sidewalk and the street or a strip not less than four feet wide adjacent to the street where there is no sidewalk and the vision clearance triangle area on any corner lot noxious weeds means noxious rank vegetation such as cockleburs poison ivy poison sumac poison oak wild parsnip spotted knapweed leafy spurge ragweed burdock canadian thistle marijuana english charlock wild mustard field bindweed goatsbeard field dodder indian mustard oxeye daisy sow thistle harmful barberry bull thistle and wild lettuce noxious weeds do not include native grasses and plants indigenous to western wisconsin that are 1 planted and maintained as part of a garden or for landscaping purposes  or 2 planted and maintained for erosion control weed control or designated wildlife areas plantings means trees shrubs bushes and other common landscape plantings wetland means a swampy or marshy area and include the areas immediately surrounding ponds river beds and streams wooded area means an area densely covered with trees and shrubs part   prohibitions a untended rank and unmanaged growth of vegetation on any property within the city which is visible from any public way street sidewalk or alley is declared to be a public nuisance and may be abated in accordance with the procedures set forth in this chapter part   responsibilities a on property having lawns of the conventional bluegrass type such conventional lawn areas shall be maintained at a height not to exceed six inches b every person shall destroy all noxious weeds on all lands which he shall own occupy or control the person having immediate charge of any public lands shall destroy noxious weeds on such lands c plantings and gardens shall be maintained so as not to present hazards to adjoining properties or to persons or vehicles traveling on public ways and shall be subject to the provisions of this code part   abatement by the city a if the provisions of this chapter are not complied with the weed inspector or designee shall serve written notice once per calendar year upon the owner lessee or occupant or any person having care or control of any such lot or land to comply with the provisions of this chapter b if the person upon whom the notice is served fails neglects or refuses to cut and remove or to cause to be cut and removed such weeds grass brush or other vegetation within five days of date of such notice or if no person can be found in the city who either is or claims to be the owner of such lot or land or who represents or claims to represent such owner the weed inspector or designee shall cause such weeds grass brush and other vegetation on such lot or land to be cut and removed c the actual cost of such cutting and removal and other costs associated with abatement shall be billed to the property owner by the city clerk and payable to the city within thirty 30 days actual costs shall be from the current city fee schedule payable to the city clerk if the property owner has not been in violation of during the previous three years 50 percent of the current charge will be waived under the condition that payment is received within 30 calendar days d failure to pay the city for the services billed will result in the costs being assessed against the property as a special charge per part  3910   managed natural landscaping a it shall be lawful to grow native and naturalized plants to any heights including ferns wildflowers grasses forbs shrubs and trees in accordance with an approved land management plan when said plants were obtained not in violation of local state or federal laws no employee of the city may undertake to damage remove burn or cut vegetation on a managed natural landscape incorporating native plants except those specifically prohibited herein and except on order of a court of record following a hearing at which it is established that noxious weeds exist in a managed natural landscape and that a condition creating a clear and present hazard to public health or safety has arisen an action for a court order under this subsection shall provide that the destruction cutting or removal of vegetation shall be selective unless general cutting destruction or removal is necessary to eliminate the offending condition b it is not the intent of this legislation to allow vegetated areas to be unmanaged or overgrown when such growth provides either a direct health hazard or provides a demonstrated breeding ground for fauna known to create a safety or health hazard the city recognizes that a limited number of species may be indicators of neglect a condition which may adversely affect human health or safety the city has specifically defined certain noxious weeds recognized to be indicators of neglect c any owner or operator of land in the city may apply for approval of a land management plan for a natural lawn one where the grasses exceed six inches in height with the department of community development subject to provisions of this chapter d revocation of land management plan the land management plan may be revoked for failure to comply with the approved plan notice on intent to revoke the land management plan shall be appealed to the board of appeals all applications for appeal shall be submitted within fifteen 15 days of notice of intent to revoke a land management plan e application requirements each application for a land management plan shall be on a form provided by the department of community development and shall be accompanied by a fee from the current city fee schedule payable to the city clerk the department of community development shall send a copy of the application to all owners of property situated in whole or in part within two hundred 200 feet of the property for which a land management plan has been requested if within fifteen 15 days of receipt of a copy of the application at least fiftyone 51 percent of such property owners file written objections to the application with the department of community development the department of community development shall refer the application to the board of appeals for hearing and decision according to the provisions of this code f application for appeals the owner or operator of land in the city may appeal a decision of the department of community development for a land management plan all appeals shall be to the board of appeals of the city which shall hear such appeals all applications for appeals shall be submitted within fifteen 15 days of notice or denial of the land management plan part   exclusions a this chapter shall not apply to 1 wooded areas  or 2 wetlands part smoking in public places banned footnotes  4  editors note  adopted  repealed the former  and enacted a new as set out herein the former pertained to and derived from smoking in public places banned the provisions of wis stats as amended by 2009 wisconsin act 12 relating to the prohibition of smoking in variously described enclosed places are hereby adopted and made part of this code by reference penalties for each violation shall be as prescribed in general penalty of this code as is prescribed in a warning notice shall be issued to the person in charge for the first violation  8102010 occupancy limits for bars and restaurants purpose the purpose of this chapter shall be to regulate the occupancy of bars and restaurants licensed by the city and made open or available to the public at large or to members whether free of charge subject to a cover charge or whether on a membership basis it is in the interest of the public health safety and welfare to prevent overcrowding in such facilities so as to avoid injury or deaths which may be a direct or indirect result of overcrowding  part   adoption of state regulations by reference wis adm sps 376 is adopted by reference and shall constitute a portion of this chapter  part   2 5102016   definitions the following definitions shall control interpretation and application of this chapter day means a twentyfour 24 hour period of time commencing with twelve am and ending with eleven fiftynine pm facility means any licensed premises open to the public whether in the form of a restaurant or a bar tavern pub or other premises licensed for the on sale consumption of fermented malt beverages wine or intoxicating liquor license means a license to engage in the operation of a facility occupants means the number of members of the public found in a facility at any given time owner means the owner of the licensed premises or the occupant thereof whether under a formal or informal lease or rental arrangement who is further denominated as the holder of a license for operation of the facility in question public means any and all persons other than the owner his or her agents and employees  part   overcrowding prohibited no facility shall allow occupants in a number exceeding the maximum established for said facility in accord with congregate in to be found upon or otherwise to sit stand or otherwise occupy loiter upon or to be located in or situated within the facility at any one time the owner of each such facility shall be required at all times to maintain strict compliance with this restriction  part   posting of occupancy limits immediately adjacent to each door or other means of public access to a facility the owner shall post a sign eighteen 18 by twelve 12 inches in size which shall contain the following information occupancy limit xxx persons in letters not less than three inches in height occupancy shall also be posted on liquor license issued by the city  part   public portion of facility to be open to inspection a at all times when the facility is open to public occupancy the owner shall afford unrestricted access to all portions of the facility which are open to the public to all city police officers fire officers ambulance and emergency response personnel and building inspectors the owner by applying for and receiving a license to operate the facility shall be deemed to consent to such entry by city officers and employees for the purposes of maintaining the safety and welfare of the public this chapter presumes that city officers and employees charged with or empowered to enforce its terms may accept the general invitation to the public to enter the premises for these purposes b upon entry to the premises for the purpose of enforcing this chapter city officers and employees may take all reasonable measures to count the number of the public present upon the premises at that time including but not limited to asking all members of the public to depart the facility for purposes of engaging in such a count c if upon counting the public present on the premises it is determined that the number is in excess of that established under at the option of the owner or the agent of the owner apparently in charge of the facility on the owners behalf either a number of persons equivalent to the excess number shall be required to leave the facility or the facility may be closed for the remainder of the day in question  part   penalties for violation violations of this chapter shall subject the owner to one or more of the following potential penalties a for each violation of this chapter a forfeiture may be assessed in accordance with the general penalty in of the municipal code and the schedule of deposits as established by the municipal judge b for the second and each subsequent violation of this chapter within a twelve 12 month period an injunction against the continued use of the facility may be sought from the circuit court c the city may in addition to or in lieu of one or both of the penalties prescribed under subsections a and b of this section pursue license revocation proceedings against the owner   part title 9  public peace morals
